text:
Welcome to How To Cook That I am Ann Reardon
and today after all of your requests for something

Pokemon Go we are going to make a giant gummy
strawberries and cream Poke ball.
This thing weighs a tonne!

The first two videos I ever made were Pokemon
ones.

Wow, that was over 5 years ago now, such low
quality filmed on my iPhone but you can go
check them out, I'll link to them at the end.

Last week we went to the other side of Australia
for holidays and to see friends and family.

And it was the ideal time to play Pokemon
go because we went to so many different locations.
Down South in WA has the best beaches.
At Yallingup beach we even found a magiKarp.
Here we go, right I got it.

You need about 500 candies to evolve this
one ... so we let it go back out into the
ocean.

In Fremantle there were gyms and pokey stops
everywhere!!

Look at that they are literally on every street
corner, our bag is full.

So we battled .... we walked far enough to
hatch eggs, We evolved heaps of Pokemon ... and

I can confirm there were no Pokemon 11 storeys
underground in the Ngilgi Caves.

Nor were there any at the end of the very
long Bussleton jetty.

And now that I'm back home there is hardly
anything around at all.

To make your own giant gummy Pokeball you'll
need...

Some gelatine,
strawberry jelly or jello,

sorbitol,
water,

sugar,
and glucose syrup or corn syrup.

And I'll put all the recipe quantities on
my howtocookthat.net website and I'll link
to that below for you.

Add the gelatin to the cold water and stir
it quickly making sure there are no dry spots.

Place the glucose syrup, jelly powder, sugar
and sorbitol into a saucepan.
And stir over high heat.

The glucose syrup will turn into liquid and
you want to keep stirring until all the sugar
crystals dissolve.

That will take a few minutes, so just keep
stirring and it will happen as it's starting
to boil.
Then just move it off the heat.

Now take the gelatine mixture and heat that
in the microwave in 30 second bursts stirring

each time until it is melted and liquid like
this, it will be quite thick.

Then pour in the hot strawberry mixture and
stir really well together, you don't want

any patches of plain gelatine, you want that
sweetness and strawberry flavour all the way
through.

Now if you want it brighter red, more like
the Poke balls, you can add a bit of red gel

food colouring to the mixture and stir that
through as well.

To make sure it doesn't stick run some oil
over the hemisphere mold, we want to be able
to get it out once we have made it.

Then pour that mixture into the mold, it smells
of strawberry candy.
Make sure it's right up the brim.
And leave it overnight to set.

Once it is set loosen around the edges using
a knife then pull it away from the side.

Tip it over and out of the mold onto some
baking paper.
Now to make the white half of the ball.

You'll need some gelatine, sugar, milk, sweetened
condensed milk, glucose syrup and white food
colour.
And you'll also need a cup of water.

Pour the milk onto the gelatine and stir it
quickly through.

Get your cup of water and add half of that
to the gelatine mixture and just put that

on any dry spots and then leave that to one
side.

Put the rest of the water into a pan and then
add the glucose syrup and the sugar and stir
over high heat until the sugar is dissolved.

Now just like before this will be about when
it just start to boil.
And then you can take it off the heat.

And again, we want to melt the gelatine and
milk mixture this time, in the microwave ... 30

second bursts making sure you stir it after
each 30 seconds because microwaves heat unevenly
until you have a nice thick liquid like this.

Add in the sweetened condensed milk, this
will help to lighten the colour and add that
creamy flavour.

Now pour in the hot sugar syrup to sweeten
it and mix that through.

Now you can add in as much or little of the
white colouring as you like.

Oil you bowl and fill it to the brim with
creamy gummy.

Pour some of the remaining mixture into two
cookie cutters for the two white circles on
the front of the Pokeball.

I'll put the sizes that I'm using for these
on the recipe post for you too.

Take the mixture that you have left and add
some dark chocolate to darken it and stir
it until it is melted all the way through.

Then you can add in some black gel food colouring
to make it black for the middle of our Pokeball.

Now you want to tip that into a round cutter
and a large circle, I am using a loose based
cake tin without the base.
And just tip that in.

This looks like licorice to me but I don't
want to flavour it licorice because I don't
actually like that flavour.

Once all of those have set, loosen the creamy
gummy from the mold and tip it out.

Now heat up a baking tray and use it to melt
one side of the medium circle.

And once a thin layer is melted underneath
add it to the top of the black circle.

And that will just set again and stick it
into place.

Then take the little circle, melt one side
and add it to the top of your stack.

Heat one side of the black disc and add it
on to the Pokeball, making sure that you get

it in the right spot because it's a little
bit hard to move around if it's not right.

Then add the red hemisphere on top of that,
again just melting the underneath of it before
you put it on, just on a hot baking tray first.
This is huge!

And you don't have to make one as big as this,
you could get a smaller hemisphere mold or

a whole tray of little hemispheres and then
you'll have little pokeballs instead.
Add the circle to the front and you're done.
Ready to go and catch some Pokemon.

I'm in Team Valour, let me know what team
you're in.

Subscribe to HowToCookThat for more cakes,
chocolates and desserts.

Click here for the recipe, here for last week's
Emoji Slushie video and here for my channel.

Champion of the week goes to 'Grace With a
Book in Her Face' who did book a review of

The Deep Enders on her channel - and you can
click to watch that here.

Pokemon go was requested this week alone ... by
KaptainSpud99 with 213 likes on that request.
